reviewText:
Verdict: RECOMMENDED

Before we get into this review, I have at least over 3000+ hours on this game, I have been playing it for 7 years I don't use the Steam version often. Oh and hey to anyone who knows Gonnakillu, Scottyj and my 17 other toons from Argonneson (add me if you do <3)

The actual combat system is definitely one of the best I have used in MMO's I have played my fair share of MMO's and in my opinion the combat system/engine in this game tops all of them, for a game that was released in 2006 (I think) it has a really advanced combat system and I would call it advanced for games today.

To actually have fun with this game you do not even have to have friends playing with you as there is a great group engine which allows everyone around the world to be connected together and play with eachother, you can mark yourself as LFG (Looking For Group). The game is also fun while soloing through quests but you can also have support from hirelings, which is an friendly AI which you purchase to hire for an hour (time doesn't go on whilst not in quests/wildernesses). Speaking of the AI's, although they are sterotyped to be stupid as a pinecone they are actually very useful to have at times and they're very well developed.

For classes/races there are so many options to pick, I think there are a total of 14 classes, but that can change at anytime because Turbine are always updating the game with new classes/races, I also think there is a total of 14 races now that they've added in Gnomes, unforunately I haven't been on to see this yet. The race you pick can also effect your class stability and changes your stats such as Charisma, Wisdom, Strength, for example a Halfling will have decreased Strength and a Drow will have decreased Intelligence, this is also a very good system that stops very over powered builds coming in game.

The servers itself are very good, I do not ever experience lag, whenever I do it is on my end, there are not many maintenances that occur.

The game is F2P but after a certain level lets say, 12 it is very hard to progress without some adventure packs and you will find yourself grinding the same quest a lot, VIP is quite cheap for a monthly subscription, but you can also just buy the adventure packs individually and in your own time. If you are P2P'ing you will have a better time with the game as you will not have to ransack every F2P quest out there as a lot of adventure packs are added frequently that you will have access to once released (as a VIP) You can also either the races/classes or get them for free with VIP, but you can also earn the in-game without implementing a single penny into the game via favor which you earn with every quest you complete, the amount of favor points you get is increased if you do the quest on a higher difficulty (please note there is a lot of F2P classes/races but there is a lot of P2P classes/races as well).

This game can also be used to make a lot of friends which could lead you into a high level guild which makes the whole experience a lot better and more fun. Your guild you have joined or created can also get an airship, you may unlock the first airship at level 20 (guild level) I believe and you will start to unlock better airships gradually when you increase your guild level, these airships can be brought by in game currency (platinum, gold, silver, cooper etc) or Turbine Points. These airships aren't just there for design though, they are able to have buffs on then which increase your stats which are very useful especially when going on high level raids.

The PvP feature is outstanding, I guilty enough, have spent most of my hours in the PvP areas which are normally located in taverns, the most populated one being the Wayward Lobster in Harbor. Although in my server it isn't as populated as it used to be once be (the good ol' days :'( ) it is still a fun feature which you can mess around with friends with, there are also game modes such as capture the flag and all of that shenanigans but I am not sure if it is working shape as I haven't heard of it for a while.

The character creation is an extraodinary engine, it has many options to pick with which can be used ot make a already built build (highly recommended for new players) or a custom build which you can decide where your points go and what spells you decide on. You can even choose your own aliginment (not sure if spelt right) In the past couple of years they've implemented a lot of good features such as new skill trees, epic feats, epic destinies etc and this has changed the game a lot as there is so much more to do. This game, in my opinion, has the best charactor creation engine out there.

If you decide to buy VIP right off the hook make sure you DO NOT start an iconic character straight away as this will take you to level 15 and as a newbie you will be absolutely crushed in quests (that is if you know how to get to quests by that point) make sure you try one of the beginner classes and start off slow and get the drift of the game first, get a character to level 1-15 instead of skipping the levels.

An outstanding feature is True Reincarnation which can be used at level 20 to set you back to level 1 but it will be like you are creating a whole new character as you can pick a whole new race and class but it will be a lot more stronger, powerful and it will give you a lot more options, if you true reincarnate again you will be stronger and more powerful than your 2nd life, after your 3rd life you will have one more boost your points you can add onto your stats etc until it will stay the same and if you do one life on every class you will get a feat that will stick onto you forever called Completionist" this drasticlly improves your stats etc
date: although this will take a lot years to do
recommended: I know a few people myself who has done it
hoursPlayed: I myself have a family member who has done it.\n\nThe community in the game is great

reviewText:
The graphics are datedbut the gameplay is unique.
Everything is instanced (only the city is a player hub)
Dungeons contain traps to be disarmed and secret doors to be found.
Different enemies have different abilities or immunities.
Most MMO's have the holy trinity, in this game you need more than a trinity to get the maximum of every dungeon.

My biggest cons are these :
The crafting system is way too complicated
It is free to play until lvl 5-8,after these level you'll be grinding the same 2 dungeons unless you buy some content.

reviewText:
I don't understand how (since the unfortunate and untimely demise of SWG), anyone can play any other MMORPG.  I mean, in all fairness, other titles might have the advantage of being a venerable title (WOW), or have a massive fan following (either FF XI/XIV), but when it all comes down to style, playability, and taking full advantage of the MMO perks, by incorporating them into the games construction, DDO, has done exactly what it set out to do...Emulate the adventures of the pen & paper game that has reached critical acclaim from loyal fans the world over.

All the versatility of the tabletop format is right here at your fingertips.  You want to customize your stats and feats to build the most critical to form shield & sword knight, emphasizing value of honor and virtue, or become a shadow walker with deft fingers and mythic ability?  You can.  In fact, you can be both at the same time!

Multiclass?  Yes, please!  I found myself easily bored by other MMO's and their linearal ability trees; maxing out my characters to get a taste of their potential, only to wish that there was more I was capable of doing.

WOW?  Pffft... not if the game paid me!  DDO is the closest experience to the tabletop format as you can possibly get, without actually drawing up a world yourself.

And trust me, if you enjoy this game for even a minute, do yourself a favour, go pick up some dice.  When you experience all that D&D can be, you'll never turn your back.  It's the ultimate high.

reviewText: I've been playing DDO for about 3 or 4 years. It's a game I play all summer, every summer, and it brings that happy kid feeling back into me. This game is so nostalgic. I love the leveling system and how you can set up parties to play with others. This game has so much in it, I can play for 12 hours straight, wake up, and start playing. Everyone who likes leveling up, picking cool spells, or enchanting weapons like Greatswords or Longbows should give this game a try. I suggest playing to at least level 4. If you don't buy a subscription though, I think the standard cap is either 8, 10, or 12. I haven't played in a while.

reviewText: I've played this game for years now (way, way before it was on steam which I honestly just moved to) and it has been a great game. It's a really great game honestly and I love it. The creators are still supporting in and releasing updates and it's pretty awesome. However it's player base has started to dwindle and that is hurting it a lot. It was never what you could call high profile but it did have a crap ton of players on it. But now it can be hard to find others. It's possible to get around this if you know what to look for though. First of all, play during the day, esp. on weekends and there will be a good number of people around. Second of all, be careful what server you pick as characters can't move between them. To get around this I suggest using Argonnessen (you might have to scroll to find it). It has a really active player community still and there are a lot of guilds looking for players. Third, JOIN A GUILD PLEASE, just do it, if you are having a hard time finding people that's probably because you aren't in one. It helps, a lot, it really does. As far as finding one goes, hang around the harbor or korthos island (after you kill the dragon, you can't join one before that) and someone will probably try and recruit you to their guild. I know a guild (not mine, I founded my own a while ago and try and keep it kind of small) called Tycoons of Tommorow has been really active lately as well as really into recruiting, so they would be a good choice. Fourth, if a guild isn't helping or your fellow members aren't logged in, use the social pannel. It's there for a reason. It's made to show you all parties looking for members to do a quest. If you want to do a quest that isn't on that list, create your own looking for members party (the tool to do so is also in the social pannel). On the issue of FTP, that lasts for about 7 to 8 levels (that's a lot more than you think, you have to rank up 5 times per level and ranking up is a lot like what leveling is in another game) so you can still get some play time in before you run in to that really badly. HOWEVER, remember this is a bussiness, the company has to make money otherwise they can't have a game so eventually they need you to buy something. Don't get upset about this if you don't want to pay, go play flash games or something online it doesn't really matter. If you are willing to get over that, be willing to pay a little, you can get a subscription or buy individual content. I suggest buying the individual content which you do through the in game store, it's not too expensive and it never expires so it's a lot like buying DLC content for another game. Next DON'T expect this to be the pen and pencil game. It's different, HOWEVER, it really did inherit the heart and soul of D&D. Character building is almost strait out of D&D 3.5 edition and is very (almost deceptively) complex. It's easy to mess up so read a couple tutorials or pick a default build. Whatever you do, don't play the wizard, pick sorcerer, they do everything better and both are free. Wizards just really suck on non-reencarated builds. For beginners I suggest picking the Barbarian or Paladin classes. Both are really good and easy to play (Paladins just got an update and are stupidly powerful right now, I would go with a Human or Dwarf Paladin). Player abilities take a little ispiration from 4.0 (good things not all the terribleness) so that you don't have to make a lot of basic attacks and it's really intuitive. Quests are also really nice as long as you aren't too concerned with your exp. per minute (which honestly just takes the fun out of the game). Take your time and read and listen to the stories, they are pretty great. And lastly just have fun with it. It's free at first so it doesn't hurt at all to try. So come on and play, If you are on Agronnessen and you see a character with the surname Requiem, say hi, I'll see if I can't help you get started.

reviewerDisplayName: fat lip is my spirit animal
reviewText:
Really glaring flaws that are really putting me off.

Melee combat is very hit or miss, I enjoyed it on a monk but a dual rapier rogue ended up being a nightmare at some points,(maybe it was the attack speed?) if the enemy chooses to move at all you will have just about no chance of hitting them and this will happen frequently against casters. Maybe this was just from the last dungeon I was in but I was not able to hit the orcs at all once they moved, and they moved VERY frequently when hit, and it took a moment after they stopped before I would be able to continue dealing damage.  I was doing very well in a dungeon three levels higher than I was supposed to be in but these things seriously hampered my progress to a point where I had to completely stop and leave, I will never step foot in that area again because it was a very nasueating experience having orc casters with blur and negative level abilities constantly shift to avoid damage made them literally unhittable, it was an actual brick wall.

NPC spellcasters that are not your hirelings have an infinite amount of spellpoints, so anything you fight will never run out of an infinite font of fuel to burn your ♥♥♥ to the floor. If you try to wait any negative levels (feels like three minutes+ per negative level..) you incur they will continue to spread buffs, and the moment you get in range you get slapped with even more.

The dungeons are really neat when its not go left or right into rooms that have nothing but filler mobs with a few crates that *might* contain something worth selling and for the conquest and ransack xp boosts. Although I feel like for this reason there are some quests that arent really even viable to do because they are just way too long and you could have done much more in that time.

I don't even think this review is done but these were just some thoughts so far.

reviewText:
So I have been playing this game for about 6-7 years now and its still my main backup MMO.

The character creating/leveling up system is like DND and is one of the most unique systems in my mmo expirence , excluding asian mmo's.

The whole game is instance based, so each quest is its own instance.
This allows for quest solo'ing if you are prepared enough on Elite the highest difficulty of the 4(Cassual, Normal, Expert and Elite).

The group finding system is involved and if you have played the latest WOW expantion and used the premade system you will instantly be familiar with it.

My favorit part of this MMO is that you can reincarnate your character when it reaches level 20+.
Reincarnation allows you to reroll your whole character to level with better stats and more power than a normal character example: Reincarnating a barbarian in to a level 1 char it gets increased HP per level.

And there is much much more!

Lately they improved both the Barbarian, the bard and the paladin they also added random champions(improved mobs) to quests and wilderness zones. and thats just scraping the surface

P.s.
The ingame community is one of the best community you will find in an online game!

reviewText:
DDO is a great game filled with meticulous character planning, questing, leveling and even more character planning. Despite how it sounds, it's actually very pleasing. Overall gameplay experiences are positive and it's not bad on the eye either. DDO brings outstanding events (mabar, crystal cove, etc.), and I found these to be extremely rewarding.

However, I'm kind of sad to see DDO becoming less and less D&D in an attempt to please a more mainstream crowd. I greatly enjoyed playing it over the past years, but I find myself playing less for exactly that reason. Every update comes with it's own set of new bugs and support is sloppy. Every update seems to make the game more profit oriented, the gaming experience coming in second place. And I'll admit, I have spent my fair share of money, with no regrets.

PROs:
- Hours of fun. Find yourself a capable, well balanced party and you'll be having a good time.
- A variety of different locations, each with their own inhabitants, all equally eager to knock you down a peg.
- A very supportive community

CONs
- After hours of gameplay, going from TR to TR becomes quite a grind.
- Incompetent" (By lack of a better word) parties will prolong a quest greatly. This is not always a problem
date: but can be quite aggrevating when it takes 3 hours to complete a seemingly simple raid.\n- Bugs and poor fixes.\n- Quest mechanics have been changed
recommended:
making it next to impossible to do a quest solo.

TL;DR
DDO is still good
hoursPlayed: it just used to be better."

reviewText: I think this game is a very good rpg. I mostly play solo, so my review will be based primarily on that. Even though this game is over 8 years old, the graphics still look very nice. The dungeons and enemy designs are very well done. Its definitely a dungeon crawler. You will not be riding horses around the countryside thats for sure. I enjoy being able to hire a mercenary and summon a combat pet to help you with your solo group. Experience points are only given upon completion of the dungeon quest and not on each enemy killed. The only drawback is that you have to complete the dungeon in one sitting and some of the dungeons are very long and complicated. I started free to play and then i purchased Menace of the Underdark expansion pack during a Steam sale for $8.75 and it upgraded my account to premium. It was a fantastic buy. I do not pay a monthly fee to play this game, which is great.

reviewText:
After 400 + hours of this dealing with bugs and everything, i can safely say that this is like a love hate relationship. You wan't this game to be so good but the bugs constantly slap your immersion right in the face.

Would i wan't the hours i played back, no. Do i wan't the game to improve yes.

If you have ever played pen & paper like i did, this is a easy to digest version somewhat of the old d & d games. But it plays like an mmo of course. Theres starting to be a large variety of classes now to melt into eachother with reckless abandon. Some builds are extremely good and some are very gimped.

It takes the action based approach to a really cool place, which i really like. But that said some of its features are lacking in the sense that it's crafting system never fully matured.

The large raids require a large amount of guidance, and can fail badly and quickly because of large amounts of dammage  huge demands to mana. They removed monks ability to ressurect people which was a huge boon and needed in my opinion.

Small pets that do nothing, no mounts and no housing. Those are things id like to see in the future. And the really cool story based dungeons could lift the game somewhat, with not to much downtime mind you, it sucks to wait for minutes just looking at narration.

Well if you are new to the game and are looking for a guild, im on sarlona with my own guild Nobles of Evenstar.

reviewText:
Warning: Not a full F2P-game!

You will have to buy new mission packs to proceed to the higher ranks. You can farm the ingame-currency, but this might take you months, to get some of the most needed updates. So if you are looking for a F2P go look elsweyr ;-)

But if you are willing to invest the average price of a new pc-game then you are golden. Game offers a nice community, tons of missions, which can be run solo and many raids, which require a good team.

It does not have epic graphix, but epic fights, loot and tales, enough epicness imho.

So go RTD.

reviewText:
I came across this when I couldn't find a decent gaming group near me to play Pen & Paper DnD.

I haven't played it on Steam for a long while (Because technical reasons), but I'm pretty sure my hours played are at least double, if not triple the amount above.

It's not a carbon copy of PnP considering it's made for MMO purposes (I mean, come on, you don't REALLY want to wait six seconds for every single action, do you?) but it's a pretty good representation of it.

A dedicated player can play this game and eventually* access all its content without needing to pay a single penny.

One thing that makes this game stand out from many others out there is its replayability.
Your character isn't capped at its full potential when you reach max level, no.

You can Reincarnate" characters to make them stronger on recreation
date: giving them extra perks and bonuses
recommended: allowing you to build a better character from level 1 without deleting and re-creating it.\n\nWith time
hoursPlayed: you can go through all the Classes with a single character
voteText: no need to create different characters for different classes
helpfulPercent: though you can still do that
votesHelpful: if you so choose.\n\nIt's also a rather friendly community overall
votesTotal: so don't hesitate to always ask for help in-game!\n\n*After excessive grinding across multiple servers for currency you can use in the in-game Store."

reviewText:
It was good at first. Then it all went downhill once the second expansion came out.
It hurts me to play it, because I realize how alive and good it once was.
Doesn't help that the content-purchase system here is much more greedy than in LotRO. At least the content was reasonably priced there and you could get Turbine Points rather easily...
I've played since 2011, quitting for a while after each time I true reincarnated. The content is enjoyable at first, but can get repetitive quickly, especially if you're on later lives and need more exp. Balance is... out of whack, and has been...
There's more of a focus on soloing now, as many players have quit in the last few years, and most servers are lacking in population, at least from what I've seen. At least the character creation is very extensive. I've always liked that.

reviewText:
Simply the best Dungeons & Dragons roleplaying platform out there.
Neverwinter turned pay to win and locks you into a narrow window for each class.
DDO allows a wide range of customization letting you play how you want.
DDO does have pay elements, but you can play for free and still expect to be useful in the end game. You also earn Turbine Points for playing, allowing you to quicky move to a premium account. (Play a few hours, earn points, and buy something in the store)
I still haven't gone through all of the content in this game.

reviewText:
Subscription:
I played it many years ago(2007-2008) and it was great as a subscription game. Alot of content to keep you intrested in and Reincarnation system makes for alot of replay value. There seems to be alot of improvements that i have not yet fully explored yet (due to the fact I am no longer a subscriber). If you are willing to pay the subscription fee, it is worth it to pick this one up for a bit till you get bored of it. All ten of my characters from back when I stopped are still all there(cant access most of them due to the limit of 4 characters for a premium account)


F2P: NOT RECOMMEND ;
I reciently picked it back up to see the changes in the game, but as f2p this game is a horrible money grab. You pretty much can not do anything worth while as a f2p. From what I have seen there is no possible way to get to max lvl as f2p. I can not recomend this to anyone who isn't willing to sub to it if you plan to play it for a while. Good way to see if you care for it or not to sub though.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nDD is literally the best game i have played. From the action combat to the traps in dungeons its awesome. Another plus is that almost any pc can run it decently. Theres quite a few classes (16 if i remember right) that you can chose from which fall into 4 main categories. you have stealth range warrior and mage essentially. It is however very instanced but the load time isnt to bad even for low spec pcs. Each weapon is strong agenst specific enemys such as blades being ineffective agenst skeletons but maces are and vice versa for undead. If your looking for a game thats fun to quest grind and etc in this is the game for you. It gets even more fun when you get a whole guild in an area. It makes you feel very powerfull. There are plenty of toutorials to help you through the game so i would highly suggest at least trying it. If its not for you then whatever you just had a bit of fun and passed some time!

reviewText: If you have Windows 8/8.1 don't even bother with this game. Windows 8 dropped support for .NET 1.1, which this games **LAUNCHER** uses. Turbine refuses to switch it over to MS VS C++, which runs the LOTRO Launcher.\n\nOne can't help but wonder what else is being neglected in the actual game, if the company can't even take the time to copy and alter their existing LOTRO Launcher to work with DDO's game client.

reviewText:
Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game.
I have played it for years and both love and hate it.
Many times have I deleted all my characters and vowed never to return to it.
Many times have I relented and given it another go.
Each time the conviction becomes stronger to leave it alone.
Finally, I have decided to play one last time, this time not to delete.  I will be playing a warforged sorcerer, for the heals and the burst dps.  I'll be focusing on the conjuration school of magic for my feats, to improve the DC of the spells so they aren't resisted as easily and saved against, such as when the mob takes half or no damage.  I believe the conjuration school is the one with the most damage spells, if not then whichever school.  No metamagic feats, except maybe heighten, for bosses.  Having many spell points means not having to use only spell-like abilities, where metamagic feats have no cost.  At least that is the theory.  Another option would be warforged wizard, but i'm just not thrilled by the wizard skill tree, and its poor showing of SLA's.  Another option would be maximize and the other damage boosting feat with a sorcerer tree, but then you can't cast any other damaging spells without turning off the feats, which is not a big deal, but you lose the feats you would have used for the improved DC (difficulty c-something).
.
And that brings us to the reason I think this game is broken.  TR, or True Reincarnation.
For whatever reason, they chose to give you the option of reincarnating as a level 1 again but with a bonus feat and a couple of bonus stat points, and maybe something else.  I think it is total bs.  There are those who have done it a thousand times and are so far beyond the 'noob' who is on his 'first life' it is really quite pathetic.  And to expect any new player to embrace this concept and desire to play this way is even more pathetic.  It is really very embarrassing.  I'm almost embarrassed to be playing it at all, but I have such a history with the game that it just felt right to have a presence in it, with at least one character.
.
Will I eventually reincarnate and play again, with either the same class/race or some other?  I don't know.  I doubt I will ever get to level 20.  I doubt the game will last much longer.  Somehow there is a devoted subscriber base that pays for at least one developer who regularly cranks out some sort of updates that I really never get to play, having always deleted my characters before getting to that level.
.
There is one benefit to reincarnating, for a f2p player like me, which is the ability to start new quests on hard or elite, on your 2nd and 3rd lives, respectively.  I don't really see it as a benefit, but the developer got to eat so they have to gimp the f2p/freemium player somehow.
.
The alternative is to subscribe, for maybe a month, maybe more, depending on your bent.  I have taken a no-subscribe vow for all games, since quitting wow.  I subscribed for a month to ddo, but they charged me for 2 months, and I didn't even keep playing, it just got so lame running behind the 'ubers' trying to keep up.  But it turns out this is really every game.  Bunch of ubers admiring each other.  Back-slapping society.  The difference is that in DDO you start over at level 1 every 20 levels.  You can continue to the 'epic' levels now, but who would do that?  You will always be lacking the reincarnation feats other characters have accrued.
.
Some people will say, 'well, that is the game, what's not to like?'.  And I say, be nicer to your fremium players.  Don't be so exclusive.  Don't be so elitist.  Make your game inviting to all, not just a few who fall for the line you are playing out.
.
I've purchased nearly every questpack the game has, except for a couple of the newest ones that are very high level anyway, so I probably will never play them.  This is stupid if I ever subscribe, even for a month.  So, I will play my punk-♥♥♥ warforged sorcerer and do the quests solo, and maybe reincarnate, if I ever get there.  I was going to play a halfling sorcerer or something equally pathetic, but everyone just says, 'why aren't you a warforged?'.  As I said, broken game.  I could play any other character, of whatever 'build' is recommended, but I like the sorcerer.  Actually, I mostly just don't like the other classes, with their stick swinging whackwhackwhack nonsense all the damn time.
.
So, I will see you in the game, maybe, though not with this name, lol.  Or, perhaps you will understand my reasoning and stay away.  For the most part, I will be staying away, but sometimes, just for the memories, I will come back to it, run a quest, deconstruct some items, polish my whatever item, and feel the nostalgia.  Cheers to a dead game, DDO, how ever much longer it takes for it to realize that and quit trying to reincarnate.
.

reviewText: As one of the original founders (my guild's name, Gtb, is still on the monument), I returned after some years to the game in the hopes of enjoying it once more. A poor decision on my part, I'm afraid.\nThe game says free to play
date: but, in fact, the game is a microtransaction farm. It's sparsely populated, and the only way for your wallet to survive is to join a guild - in this game, if you're playing solo, understand that death has a dollar sign attached to it. And, you're going to die a lot. The game's mechanics have encouraged a scarcity environment, to ensure microtransactions, and the repetitive gameplay means a lot of grinding.\nIf I knew a few weeks ago what I knew now, I wouldn't have wasted my time. Avoid this game - the whole experience has degraded.

reviewText:
I wanted so much to love this game.

It is wonderful if you loved 3.5 D&D (I did) but the whole thing creaks under its age. The player base is small, cliquey and more overpowered then any noob could ever aspire to. The game is buggy and the free version extremely frustrating (so much content is locked). The paid version is ALSO frustrating since, even when you pay the subscription cost, you have to buy upgrades etc. seperately.

I think I'm going to try again, at some point, and see if I can find the fun but I'm not hopeful. The cost of just a few months playing it as pay2win would pay for an entire premium game (Witcher 3). Maybe it will just become my drunken FTP ex and I'll booty-call the servers when I feel bad about myself.

reviewText:
i would recommend this game.. generally..however this a good/bad review
GOOD:
*on one hand you hve the amazing battle mechanics, they are really interesting and fun and make every class prove a challenge in some form
*the customizability is insane, you have the ability to be comepletely different which is awesome but can ♥♥♥♥ up your character if used inproperly
*an enjoyable play style with friends
*nice taverns to relax
*pretty good graphics
*very good races
*and enough classses to occupy your time for quite a bit
BAD:
*this game has a company on it that has the legal ability to access your computer at any time, a serious computer breach
*mostly pay to play/play to win
*very little in the way of free dungeons
*so much grinding it hurts (it literally hurts XD)
*a very long and unsatisfying leveling process
*ability to waste hours of work by inproperly customizing your character
*race variety a bit extreme, makes it hard to know whats best for what
*you can buy level boosts (which i do have) these give major player enhancements, making it PAY TO WIN

Synopsis(summary):this game is the epitome of all terrible mmos combined into one little messy montage of hell. i mean if you want to waste your time completely and utterly, play this game, it's hell; however, you do have quite a bit of space for friendly enjoyment with your peers but this game shouldnt be played solo, you'll kill yourself. It is what it is, and this game is kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥, if you are gonna pay 15 a month, spend it on WoW. I still play because this game does give some fulfillment.

Have fun and good luck, this game isnt for all.

reviewText:
Just a note before I begin..... I have been playing this game for 4 years prior to accessing through Steam.

This game is what a good Action RPG should be.  It has almost infinite replayability!

Characters aka Toons" - with 8 regular races
date: 4 Iconic races and 13 classes......the combinations are endless.  Each class has multiple ways to build them and with multi-classing
recommended: the tweaking never stops.  This is the biggest strength of the game in my opinion.  Add in the Epic Destinies in the later levels and customization continues to increase.  Each Resurrection adds a "Past Life" bonus which keeps you grinding for more.\n\nContent - There are tons of quests! A large amount of them are set in the Realm of Eberron.  A couple of years ago they expanded to include the Forgotten Realms (Eveningstar
voteText: etc.).  The content includes Wilderness areas
helpfulPercent: Quests and Raids.  There are a large diversity in quests with puzzles sprinkled through out.  The difficulty is adjustable in each case.\n\nFree-to-play - When reading reviews of MMOs
votesHelpful: this seems to be one of the biggest factors for people liking or disliking the game.  Is this game Free-to-play?  Yes
votesTotal: it is.  You can unlock everything in the game for free......with a good amount of grinding.   It is possible to play totally free by earning Turbine Points (TP) for completing quests.  TP is the DDO Store currency for purchasing Quest packs
votesFunny: cosmetics
commentsCount: specialty potions
column16: etc.  Is there the opportunity to pay real money for advantages?  Yes
column17: there are.   You can purchase TP with real money.  There are also upgrades to purchase for you character like ability and skill tomes.  So technically you can advance yourself by spending some real money
column18: however the only way to get the great gear in the game is by grinding for it.  I played 2 years for free before finally going VIP cause I love the game so much and thought
column19: why not....this is where I spend most of my time.\n\nCommunity - The community is largely made up of older people
column20: reliving the days of PnP online in video game format.  Guilds are a good way to meet people and also gain some help.  There are opportunities for roleplaying if you find the right people.  The majority of players are good people if you are willing to learn the right way to play.... that means listening to those who know what they are doing
column21: sticking to the plan and playing within your limits.  There are lots of resources for help online\n\nI have enjoyed this game for a long while and will continue to do so as long as the updates keep rolling in"

reviewText:
Awesome game.
See that large number on the time played above? Yeah that has only been since it got on Steam.

Yes the graphics are dated and some of the base D&D mechanics are creaking under the weight of all the add-ons done over the years. Most of the problems with mechanics tend to show up at the upper level ranges (20+)

Many of the recent adjustments to classes has taken some of the difficulty edge off of the lower levels as power creep has reared its head.
-----------

For the absolute best DDO experience:
get 3-4-5 friends that have zero experience playing. Have everyone go through the tutorial (it is solo only).
Set up a schedule of play time and request that no one plays at all outside of the group time, no spoilers!
Dont go read about how best to play the game or the best builds , etc.
The exploration and learning on your own when it is all fresh to the whole crew is priceless.

Some dungeons have you thinking with your fighter ,barbarian or sorcerer you are the baddest MoFo ever.
Next dungeon you are cheering on the rogue who is sneaking around a room full of big, bad Ogres, that would squash him in no time flat if they see him/her, picking up the soul stones(dead PCs) of the entire party to take them back to the shrine to be raised from the dead.

===========================
Lots to do as free to play so no need to pull out the CC right away.
If you follow the above plan for best experience by time you get to where you feel the 'need' to pay, you will gladly be screaming take my money
date:
now!"

-----------------------
One word of caution about making characters;
Many of the older dungeons have the unfortunate MMO min/maxer design problem.
You will run in to somethings that require X Strength score to open or Y skill points to trick an NPC will seem really high.
The desiginers couldn't make the stat requirements too low where a balanced character could complete with out making things trivial for the min/maxers.

Just keep that in mind when building that maxing or nearly maxing your primary ability scores is suggested and likewise it is better to have a few skills that are maxed rather than a bunch of skills with low investment.
~~~~~~~~"

reviewText: I do recommend this game.  I'm a age-old D&D fan, and the flexibility of this game to make the character you want, change classes, vary weapons, etc... it's just awesome.  The dungeons and combats are much more unique than most other MMO's I've played (still not as great as solo games where you are the center of the universe)... but hey, you can play it with friends which is cool.  I was worried about the reviews, expecially the costs... but some of the posts are dated and no longer accurate.  For instance, it doesn't cost any $ to level up.  I'm now about level 8, and finally blew $35 on the game and don't really plan on spending more... that might mean I top out and don't get to the highest levels, but I don't plan on playing more than a year.  If you do go the Free to play option, I highly do NOT recommend spending any $ until you get to be level 6 or higher.

reviewText: As I am new to online pc gaming (aside from Secondlife) (although not new to gaming on console) I find that I really enjoy playing DDO as I can play by myself if I choose or along with others. There are many quests and challenges to choose from or I can just wander around aimlessly and meet new friends without time limits. The game play is pretty easy to figure out, even for someone who knew absolutely nothing of how to use any of the inventory items or how to do any moves.  Within a couple hours I was running around with a few quests under my belt, some money and didnt look so noobish which was a wonderful thing. reviewText:
As a long time player of the dice and paper version, I find this version of D&D pretty relaxing. You can solo most quests and the ones that need a group are fairly easy to find a party for.
Actual Role Play is kinda weak but it can be found if you look for it.
Advancement is slow as you have to advance a total of 5 action points and ranks before you have enough XP to level your class, but each advancement in the action point/rank builds towards your skills.
Dual classing/ Multiclassing is easy and recommended, specially if you plan on going mainly solo.
But for a free game, I recommend trying it out at least.

reviewText:
DDO is really easy to get in to, but also has more complexity than any other MMO out there.

Where in normal MMO's you pick a class and a race and then the only choice you get from there on out is the choice of which talents to take, which makes little to no difference.

In DDO, everything you choose will affect you. If you choose the wrong race for your class you might end up reducing some important stats.

While this game is best played when you're subscribed, and it's sadly only got US based servers as of right now, i can honestly say that this is one of the best MMO's out there.

In normal MMO's you pick up a quest, go out and kill 20 of X and return only to get asked to kill 40 of Y.

In DDO you talk to people, listen to their troubles and you go into dungeons, and deal with their problems. Every quest in DDO is an adventure in itself.

Since the game is Free-2-Play, i can only say.. Give it a chance, it's honestly the best MMO on the market as of right now.

reviewText:
Before I say anything, The 26 hours played on steam is false. I've played this without steam for at least 3 thousand hours.

5 years of playing this game and paying for a VIP subscription is all that needs to be said.
And then again, I've got things to say:

pros:
+amazing dungeons
+great community (mostly)
+HUGE variety of builds and character options
+addicting
+quests have: puzzles, a nice story, good voice acting, huge potential for team play
+rewarding combat system
+intricate and in depth skill and feat trees

cons:
-slightly steep skill curve
-the random chinese self healing solo player that ruins your fun
-lots of the really awesome quests either need to be bought, earned using turbine points (free or bought), or earned through VIP. there are also 2 expansions currently, which both also require to be bought even as a VIP, although they are simply spectacular (Update 14 - Menace of the udnerdark, is an amazing and must have expansion, its quite possibly the one expasion everyone needs to have being so awesome.)

pro/con, depends on your preferences:
=quests arent afraid to outright obliterate you if youre unprepared.
=crafting system is incredibly intricate, some like it, some dont.
=need to get over fact that graphics are of an upgraded 7 year old game, although they have withstood the test of time.

reviewText: I do recommend this game.  I'm a age-old D&D fan, and the flexibility of this game to make the character you want, change classes, vary weapons, etc... it's just awesome.  The dungeons and combats are much more unique than most other MMO's I've played (still not as great as solo games where you are the center of the universe)... but hey, you can play it with friends which is cool.  I was worried about the reviews, expecially the costs... but some of the posts are dated and no longer accurate.  For instance, it doesn't cost any $ to level up.  I'm now about level 8, and finally blew $35 on the game and don't really plan on spending more... that might mean I top out and don't get to the highest levels, but I don't plan on playing more than a year.  If you do go the Free to play option, I highly do NOT recommend spending any $ until you get to be level 6 or higher.

reviewText:
Dungeons & Dragons Online (DDO) plays sort of like a hack-and-slash game as opposed to a more turn-based ability-heavy MMO like WoW. You control your character with WASD as per the norm, with things like blocking and rolling available. Attacking is done by holding down the left mouse button, and items, abilities, and spells are used with whatever you decide to use them with, the default being the 1-0 number keys. Everything's in real time, though some spells, abilities, and other things can take a little while to cast.

Easily the strongest part of DDO (and D&D) is the character customization. Want to make a melee mage? Go for it! Want to put some different caster in your caster, so you can cast while you cast? It'll be horribly gimpy, but go for it! Aside from alignment restrictions (Barbarians and Bards can't be Lawful, Monks must be Lawful, Paladins must be Lawful Good, Druids have to be Neutral) and the fact that you can't be an evil alignment, you can do whatever you want. Generally, any character you build (unless you want a 19 Barbarian/1 Wizard to cast spells offensively or something else silly like that) can get through quests fine if you play, gear, etc. well, though some will obviously struggle, and it'll likely be very difficult to play through higher difficulties and raids with a gimpy character. You also might get weird looks in parties, and perhaps even some rejections, but making your own party for like-minded people is easy.

It should be noted, though, that DDO works significantly differently than D&D, and many of the things in D&D (horseback riding, climbing, spell slots, multiple attacks per round, etc.) had to be changed. You don't have a set number of spells per day; there is instead a mana system, though the mana doesn't recharge on its own and you need to use a rest shrine (in place of resting anywhere with the possibility of being ambushed in D&D) or extremely rare potions to restore it. Casters can cast a lot more spells than in D&D, and since this was one of the main drawbacks of casters in D&D, casters tend to be more powerful than melees in DDO for large portions of the game. A lot of skills in D&D (horseback, crafting, tumbling, probably most of them, actually) had to be changed significantly or removed to fit into DDO. Numbers in generally are significantly inflated in DDO (to help fit the real-time combat so you don't just die instantly when beset by two kobolds at level 1), so don't be surprised to see people getting 1k or more HP by level 28.

The game world is completely instanced; instead of running about vast landscapes (though there are some of those, I'll go over them in the next paragraph) like other MMOs, you talk to NPCs to take quests, then go to the entrance of the quests and are whisked away to wherever the quest is in an instance that is completely separate from everything else in the world and only you and your party can enter. There are currently close to 400 quests, each with their own different dungeons (though some use the same dungeon in a slightly different way), and each quest has its own objectives that you must complete in order to finish it. Most of the quests are generally fairly static (as in not random), though almost all of them have optional objectives, secret areas, and things like that. Some of them have multiple ways to reach the end and some have multiple ways to finish the quest, though for the most part there's a clearly defined objective and one or a few different ways to get there. Quests are generally available in 4 difficulties (Casual, Normal, Hard, Elite), though some aren't. Raids, for instance, don't have a Casual difficulty.

Speaking of raids, there are currently 17 of them, ranging from level 6 to level 24. They're all fairly unique, though I don't have enough MMO experience to be able to compare them to other games. Some of them are rarely ran, though if you're patient or have friends/guildmates you can do any of them.

There also exists things called Challenges. These are timed pseudo-quests, where you have a certain objective you must complete in order to complete the challenge, and then 5 optional objectives that give you a higher score and more rewards.

There are also Explorer Areas, which are more traditional MMO areas that are open and have various things to do and explore inside them. They have XP rewards for finding certain areas, killing monsters, and killing rare monsters, and often house the entrances to quests.

In terms of endgame, at this moment, there isn't much. You can True Reincarnate your character, which recreates it at a lower level with some benefits (mostly passive things, though there are active ones). If you go from level 20 back to level 1 (there's also an option to go from 28 to 20) with this, you can create a completely brand new character of any class and race, though some things (like your name) remain the same. Other than that, there are currently no raids at the level cap (though there are many below it), so I would avoid blowing through everything to get to the level cap, and instead go slowly, play all kinds of characters, and try out all the content. This will hopefully change in the near future, as the plans are to increase the level cap to 30 and stay there to develop an end-game.

The community is relatively small, but still quite active. Finding groups can be a challenge, but if you create your own you'll most often at least get a few other people to come along. Even if you can't find people, soloing is very much doable for almost all of the game's content (though some will be extremely difficult or require you to use and abuse certain things to finish), even including some of the game's raids. There are also hirelings, which are NPCs you can buy and bring with you into dungeons. These are mostly useful for healing, either for yourself or to keep critical NPCs alive in quests, though the other hirelings can be useful. The game scales its difficulty based on your group size and composition, sometimes to a fault; it can sometimes be harder to do something in a group than by yourself.

As far as content restrictions for free players, they're not too terrible. There are more details on this topic here: http://ddowiki.com/page/Account_comparisons. There are about 120 free quests (see here: http://ddowiki.com/page/Guide_to_Free_to_Play) and challenges can be played once per day per character for free. 4 of the game's 8 races are free to play, though one of them (Drow) is easily unlocked through play. 9 of the game's 13 classes are free as well, with 2 unlockable through play (though both of them require you to unlock/buy plenty of quests to do so). In addition, completing quests and challenges will earn you Turbine Points (TP) over time which can be used to unlock quests, classes, races, extra benefits like starting characters at level 4, or various consumable and cosmetic items. It's certainly more stingy than more recent F2P games like Path of Exile where most things or even everything is given to players for free and only cosmetics can be bought, but it's not an unreasonable system.

On the whole, I'd recommend anybody at least give DDO a try (after all, it is free to play). It's certainly not for everyone, and there are issues abound, probably more than most big MMOs, but it can be a lot of fun. Don't be put off by the early questing, too; a lot of the early quests are sort of samey, featuring the same enemy and environment types. It's not until level 3-5 quests (depending on what you have available) that they start to get really interesting and unique.

reviewText:
Dungeons and Dragons.  Every geek and nerd (myself included) who grew up playing this on tabletob, with a bunch of frends, Mountain Dew, and Cheeto and Dorito dust encrusted hands, knew exactly how fun it was.  Now it's online.  And, better yet, IT'S FREE!

The game can be played as a loner (without a group), but the higher levels you gain, the easier and more fun it is as a group.  Plus, if you enjoy the RP side (what made D&D spectacular), there are plenty of players who love to keep in character.

The quests range from easy to OMFG GET ME OUT OF HERE NOW!  All are fun, and all definitely have that D&D feel.

The tutorial at the beginning when you first start is helpful and recommended.

The controls are also pretty user friendly.

Give it a try.  If you love D&D and love online games, DDO is for you.

Attacking is done by holding down the left mouse button, and items, abilities, and spells are used with whatever you decide to use them with, the default being the 1-0 number keys. Everything's in real time, though some spells, abilities, and other things can take a little while to cast.

Easily the strongest part of DDO (and D&D) is the character customization. Want to make a melee mage? Go for it! Want to put some different caster in your caster, so you can cast while you cast? It'll be horribly gimpy, but go for it! Aside from alignment restrictions (Barbarians and Bards can't be Lawful, Monks must be Lawful, Paladins must be Lawful Good, Druids have to be Neutral) and the fact that you can't be an evil alignment, you can do whatever you want. Generally, any character you build (unless you want a 19 Barbarian/1 Wizard to cast spells offensively or something else silly like that) can get through quests fine if you play, gear, etc. well, though some will obviously struggle, and it'll likely be very difficult to play through higher difficulties and raids with a gimpy character. You also might get weird looks in parties, and perhaps even some rejections, but making your own party for like-minded people is easy.

It should be noted, though, that DDO works significantly differently than D&D, and many of the things in D&D (horseback riding, climbing, spell slots, multiple attacks per round, etc.) had to be changed. You don't have a set number of spells per day; there is instead a mana system, though the mana doesn't recharge on its own and you need to use a rest shrine (in place of resting anywhere with the possibility of being ambushed in D&D) or extremely rare potions to restore it. Casters can cast a lot more spells than in D&D, and since this was one of the main drawbacks of casters in D&D, casters tend to be more powerful than melees in DDO for large portions of the game. A lot of skills in D&D (horseback, crafting, tumbling, probably most of them, actually) had to be changed significantly or removed to fit into DDO. Numbers in generally are significantly inflated in DDO (to help fit the real-time combat so you don't just die instantly when beset by two kobolds at level 1), so don't be surprised to see people getting 1k or more HP by level 28.

The game world is completely instanced; instead of running about vast landscapes (though there are some of those, I'll go over them in the next paragraph) like other MMOs, you talk to NPCs to take quests, then go to the entrance of the quests and are whisked away to wherever the quest is in an instance that is completely separate from everything else in the world and only you and your party can enter. There are currently close to 400 quests, each with their own different dungeons (though some use the same dungeon in a slightly different way), and each quest has its own objectives that you must complete in order to finish it. Most of the quests are generally fairly static (as in not random), though almost all of them have optional objectives, secret areas, and things like that. Some of them have multiple ways to reach the end and some have multiple ways to finish the quest, though for the most part there's a clearly defined objective and one or a few different ways to get there. Quests are generally available in 4 difficulties (Casual, Normal, Hard, Elite), though some aren't. Raids, for instance, don't have a Casual difficulty.

Speaking of raids, there are currently 17 of them, ranging from level 6 to level 24. They're all fairly unique, though I don't have enough MMO experience to be able to compare them to other games. Some of them are rarely ran, though if you're patient or have friends/guildmates you can do any of them.

There also exists things called Challenges. These are timed pseudo-quests, where you have a certain objective you must complete in order to complete the challenge, and then 5 optional objectives that give you a higher score and more rewards.

There are also Explorer Areas, which are more traditional MMO areas that are open and have various things to do and explore inside them. They have XP rewards for finding certain areas, killing monsters, and killing rare monsters, and often house the entrances to quests.

In terms of endgame, at this moment, there isn't much. You can True Reincarnate your character, which recreates it at a lower level with some benefits (mostly passive things, though there are active ones). If you go from level 20 back to level 1 (there's also an option to go from 28 to 20) with this, you can create a completely brand new character of any class and race, though some things (like your name) remain the same. Other than that, there are currently no raids at the level cap (though there are many below it), so I would avoid blowing through everything to get to the level cap, and instead go slowly, play all kinds of characters, and try out all the content. This will hopefully change in the near future, as the plans are to increase the level cap to 30 and stay there to develop an end-game.

The community is relatively small, but still quite active. Finding groups can be a challenge, but if you create your own you'll most often at least get a few other people to come along. Even if you can't find people, soloing is very much doable for almost all of the game's content (though some will be extremely difficult or require you to use and abuse certain things to finish), even including some of the game's raids. There are also hirelings, which are NPCs you can buy and bring with you into dungeons. These are mostly useful for healing, either for yourself or to keep critical NPCs alive in quests, though the other hirelings can be useful. The game scales its difficulty based on your group size and composition, sometimes to a fault; it can sometimes be harder to do something in a group than by yourself.

As far as content restrictions for free players, they're not too terrible. There are more details on this topic here: http://ddowiki.com/page/Account_comparisons. There are about 120 free quests (see here: http://ddowiki.com/page/Guide_to_Free_to_Play) and challenges can be played once per day per character for free. 4 of the game's 8 races are free to play, though one of them (Drow) is easily unlocked through play. 9 of the game's 13 classes are free as well, with 2 unlockable through play (though both of them require you to unlock/buy plenty of quests to do so). In addition, completing quests and challenges will earn you Turbine Points (TP) over time which can be used to unlock quests, classes, races, extra benefits like starting characters at level 4, or various consumable and cosmetic items. It's certainly more stingy than more recent F2P games like Path of Exile where most things or even everything is given to players for free and only cosmetics can be bought, but it's not an unreasonable system.

On the whole, I'd recommend anybody at least give DDO a try (after all, it is free to play). It's certainly not for everyone, and there are issues abound, probably more than most big MMOs, but it can be a lot of fun. Don't be put off by the early questing, too; a lot of the early quests are sort of samey, featuring the same enemy and environment types. It's not until level 3-5 quests (depending on what you have available) that they start to get really interesting and unique.

reviewText:
Dungeons and Dragons.  Every geek and nerd (myself included) who grew up playing this on tabletob, with a bunch of frends, Mountain Dew, and Cheeto and Dorito dust encrusted hands, knew exactly how fun it was.  Now it's online.  And, better yet, IT'S FREE!

The game can be played as a loner (without a group), but the higher levels you gain, the easier and more fun it is as a group.  Plus, if you enjoy the RP side (what made D&D spectacular), there are plenty of players who love to keep in character.

The quests range from easy to OMFG GET ME OUT OF HERE NOW!  All are fun, and all definitely have that D&D feel.

The tutorial at the beginning when you first start is helpful and recommended.

The controls are also pretty user friendly.

Give it a try.  If you love D&D and love online games, DDO is for you.

reviewText:
Today was great.  I've recently come back to DDO and reactivated my VIP subscription.  After a few days I was wondering why I ever left.  I even convinced some friends to come back and enjoy the game with me.  Then I tried to purchase some turbine points and my day really great.  Opening up the store I navigated through to purchase some coins and made sure there was enough in my steam wallet to afford it.  I don't get paid till Friday, but $20 isn't bad and it's fun.  So, once I get all that set up I click to purchase the points and...error.  No problem these things happen and there's downtime soon anyway.  I'll just try again afterwards.

Downtime is over, DDO is back up and now I log in to complete my purchase and get to playing.  Error.  Ok, so maybe I just can't use the steam wallet option.  No worries, I still have $25 in that account I'll just use my card.  So I type in my card info, choose the points I want and confirm.  Error.  Can't purchase the points.  Well, now I'm annoyed, but I'm not gonna let that get in my way.  I know I can go to the site, use the store there to but a code for the coins and input that at my account page.  It's not as handy, but it'll work.

Alright, got everything set up, found the points in the store on the site, it get 50 fewer points for the same price going this route.  But at this point I just want to get things taken care of so I can get back to playing.  So I purchase the points, get the code and head over to my account page.  Seems simple, click a button input the code and here come my points.  or....Error...really?  The code isn't valid?  I bought it 5 minutes ago, I have the page still up, I've got a confirmation email.  I'll go see if perhaps it hasn't charged my card yet.

Log into the bank and....wait...overdrafted.  Hmm...oh look I was charged for both the code I bought on the site that is invalid as well as the purchase I tried to make with my card through the store that gave me an error and told me it couldn't be completed.  Ok, so now I've moved money to my steam wallet, been charged twice from my bank account, and now we can add an overdraft charge...and I still don't have my turbine points.  What a fin day of gaming, so glad this is how I spent my day off.

Do yourself a favor, stay away from trying to support this game though purchases.  If you want to play for free, it's fine.  The game play holds up well.  But until they manage to fix the terrible system they use for purchases, just stay away.

reviewText:
To anybody who's played an mmorpg with an annoying game launcher that made you download even more stuff after installing the game? Yeah... you get the idea.

This is a pretty well made rpg game. It's got all the aspects that an rpg should have(including F2p and a premium subcriber service). Yeah kinda peeved at that because like 75% of the content ingame is P2P and the F2P stuff get's kinda boring after you grind in them for 100000000000000+ hours. Also the launcher is a little annoying on the update system as it downloads a lot of stuff if your not on for a month or something like that.

Not trying to hate on the game, it has some great things like clever item systems with multiple slot enchantments and items(doesnt sound like any other rpg game...). Fun quests(for the first time you play them). and a lot of zones(Which will take you years to reach because your too underleveled).

Ok let's get specific. At the start of your game you get to create a character. First off some of the races and classes are locked because you need a premium account to use them. and the only decent looking character i could make was human(granted I always play human, but other games really built a solid image of what else should look like and DDO kinda breaks it). Second It takes forever to level up. They have a rank system where like every 5 ranks you level up, so in reality level 2 is more like level 10 and getting levels only come from a massive amount of grinding. So be warned rushers who expect to get final level in the like the first week of the game. Commit to the game and you might actually get the level 3 in a month. In the starter areas you get a lot of the story, but after, it just gets harder and harder to find all the details. As you continue there is less and less voice acting and dialogue in the quests. And the quests, Quests are dungeon based so you cant's just enter and leave them freely, so it is kinda annoying and takes a lot of your time to complete. If you do leave you get an XP penalty or something like that. And since there are so few F2p quests/dungeons you have to keep regrinding them to get XP.

The combat is pretty fun, different enemy types have different resistances and slimes even break weapons faster. Item decay is something you have to worry about. you can fix them or just ignore them until your UBER GREATSWORD +7123 breaks because you were too lazy to unequip to fight a blob of jello. Combat animations were pretty cool, but got pretty silly after a while. There are always specific weapons that restricted like foreign weapons that your character needs to have a certain loadout to use and skillpoints gained on every rank to advance your character skill tree, except it get's really confusing especially if you multi-class with like 6 different skill trees and only like 2 points to spend. The abilites are easy to use if you know how to use hot-keys.

Now onto the life of a subscriber. If your willing to put in the money, it can be a really fun experience, you get more Xp special areas and quests that are completely restricted to the F2p Peaseants"(A.K.A 97% of the earth's population). you get easier access to pets
hoursPlayed: and cosmetic stuff. Only after you dump your life savings into the game on a monthly basis though
voteText: So go be the 3% and get the right to say that you did spend hundreds of $$$ on a fake game.\n\nSo to sum it up
helpfulPercent: either be a commited and persistent person and spend the rest of your life trying to reach level 10 or go be a premium member and do a life's work in 10 minutes with the power of cash and P2W Psychology.\n\n4/10 would grind for days again"

reviewText:
EXCELLENT game, whether free-to-play or with a paid account, DDO is absolutely worth playing!  Watch for the great sales here on Steam for the various expansions - I got BOTH Menace of the Underdark and The Shadowfell Conspiracy for less than $10 total.  I've got 200+ hours in-game as of the writing of this review.

It doesn't have to be stated that Dungeons & Dragons set the stage for all role-playing games to follow... I was there when it first started with pen & paper, that red boxed starter kit & those amazing Monster manuals(not to mention the awesomely details lead figures we would spend hours painting, letting our imaginations run wild!).  Now, so many years later(I guess I am getting old LOL), I am sooooooo loving playing Dungeons & Dragons Online.  While all the stats, abilities, buffs etc. can get rather complicated, thankfully most of that is handled in the background by the game itself. You CAN get super-detailed into your character builds, or you can be abit more casual about it and just have fun.  (if you want a much simpler but still super-fun D&D based game, check out Neverwinter)

Whether playing as a stealthy elven rogue, a magic missle-casting human wizard or a great axe-swinging dwarf fighter(and many other races/classes), you'll enjoy questing thru wilderness areas, dank catacombs, spider web-laden dungeons or hellish sureal settings out of a fiend's nightmares, DDO is a fantasy trip well worth undertaking!

reviewText: The mother of them all... the orginal, start and birthplace of fantasy games...Dungeons & Dragons. I remember playing this in my uncles basement, rolling die and imagining the beholders and kabolds. Now, I just click click to make a halfling rogue in 2 minutes, then makeing the same character sheet in 30. Times have changed. With free to play abilities D&D is a great game to play. Start from choosing class and race and a rather very in depth face creation hub and your off.  Start with a races human, halfling, elf, dwarf, half -elf, half -orc, warforged with the classes rogue, ranger, artificer, warlock, sorceror, paliden, fighter, barbarian, mage. With a straight foward ''quests lead to a dungeon'' and beat the dungeons with plenty of trainers and merchants around the game. It isn't very difficult to get the hang of. Like its tabletop version, you are pretty much an adventurer off to clear dungeons looking for epic loot. The quests and coupled dungeons do sometimes have a rather good sence of humor to it witch makes for a good read and laugh. The aspect of booby traps and puzzles within the game, in witch you need to use ''example'' my rogues search or disable trap abilities, was rather fun and challanging. The free to play aspect though does get limited as in higher levels you need to unlock along with dungeon/quests of that level. That makes for a lot of stuck between levels grinding for free to play players. Then just getting stuck. Is it a good run until then? YES  but, then the DLC is kinda needed. The graphics are decent with an oldschool feel to it where you can even  change the color of your dice and hubs for custimization. The music is spot on also to what you would expect of the fantasy world and areas. For the nostalgic and those that dont mind throwing some money at to progress.

reviewText:
***Hours listed don't reflect my time in this game since I started playing in the Beta when the game came out 10 years ago.

DDO is a fantastic game for many reasons but I'll just list the hightlights:
-Fantastic and customizable character build options
-Great quests and stories that immerse the player in the D&D Eberron and Forgotten Realms worlds (nostalgia for PnP players)
-Encourages team play; fantastic for a great co-op experience with friends
-Unique and challenging puzzles within quests that are far beyond a typical hack and slash
-A combat system that rewards twitch play and a skilled hand (common now but way ahead of its time)
-Lots of content and a good rate of content expansion
-A F2P/micro-transaction system that is reasonable, though I recommend the monthly VIP subscription

10/10

reviewText:
This is not the best mmo out there.  The graphics are dated, the controls are clunky, the user interface is lacking at times.
That said; this is a genuinly fun game.  What was changed from pen and paper is, for the most part, an improvement.
The biggest selling feature for me would be the lack of griefers.  Nobody mocks you if you have a question, people are quite willing to team up for a quick dungeon crawl, not just a high level raid (although they will team for that too).  No, not everybody is perfect, but if you want the feel of playing the first fantasy rpg, in it's best setting, with a group of friends; you can't go wrong with this.
Plus, it has Will Freaking Wheaton as a guest dm.  That alone is worth the download.

reviewText: i loved this game, it was a lot of fun and you really have to be prepared to fight if you want to survive in the zones. the reason i am not recommending the game though, is because of the pay to win factor. you can survive as a character, but advancing as a character becomes a slow grind for favor to buy adventure packs and a lot of the content is not available to the free player. i don't have any hours in on steam, but my main character, not counting the other toons i leveled to 8 or 9, was a level 13 cleric. it took a lot to get there, and i did it mostly with free content, but you are really missing a lot if you don't subscribe,

reviewText: This is a very fun game, unfortunately, it is not much for multi-player. This is a downside for me as I thought it was an actual MMO, but turns out you can solo everything. But even with that problem, it is still a very fun and engaging game, worth the download if hacking and slashing is what you enjoy. If your a die-hard roleplayer, avoid this game. You won't find ANY roleplay at all going on.

reviewText:
This game was below average. It also gave me a good amount of DIMS (simulator sickness).

There are some glaring issues with this game, like the fact that you can't unlock chests if you're using certain classes, so you don't get the reward for your quest. Other issues like being unable to disarm traps that your character has spotted.

There are other basic issues, such as having quest markers on the map and then being told that you have to be a premium member when you click on it. I'm sure they want to make more money by getting people to become premium, but wasting my time isn't going to get it to happen.

The interface is clunky, the graphics seem to be below average, the dungeons often just use the same rooms over and over again, and running back an forth for every quest can get quite tiresome.

Don't bother playing!

reviewText:
Im sorry but i really gave this game a chance...
first thing i have to say is this game is like a sterotipical mmo except guess what you have to click and hold the mouse or assign a auto attack button to even fight someone not to mention after that entire fight the only way you get any type of loot is if a treasure bag is dropped... aka you get some stupid quest based loot. So basically you fight and get nothing until you come upon a magical chest convieniently placed at the end of a dungeon. On top of that there is no open world just combat zones". You work through a combat zone to discover dungeons but guess what dungeons and combat zones work the same.
Im sorry but compared to DND at its absoulte prime aspect this games blows ♥♥♥♥. Action rpg sure but honestly its more like click on things and hope to god you swing your sword at them. Really you mean to tell me a DND game is completely based on treasure chests and crates and vases? So i kill lets say 15 humanoids and not a single one can you take their armous or weapons let alone misc gear such as food or potions. Bessssssttttt part of all is looting for example if you try to loot a single item off the ground you are required to click on it. Try clicking on a item that is sitting under two bodieds and a broken crate its ♥♥♥♥ing impossible.
Oh i feel like i forgot something.... oh yeah the DDO store. Ive played many mmos in my time but i have to say none of them is as much pay to play as DDO. You want good gear well good luck. You will run a dungeon 3000 times before you get the gear anywhere near the gear you have to pay actualy money to get. A video game that has any feature where actual currency in real life can be exchanged for anything in game is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke. Why spend hours playing is joe shmo can pay 200 bucks and be hundreds times better than you? gaaaayyyyy. i cant believe i spent the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time downloading this game"

reviewText:
Your enjoyment of the game will be entirely dependent on having a good group to work with. Unless you're able to get into the game with people who are also starting fresh (or willing to make new characters and allow you to play a role you find interesting) you will not enjoy this game at all. There is virtually nothing you can do solo in this game; you NEED to be in a party of several people to accomplish almost anything beyond level 3.

Overall the game feels incredibly slow paced and is clearly outdated. Even setting aside the graphics, there are numerous bugs that feel like they just shouldn't exist in a game that has been around this long. Expect to have to restart the client at least once every couple of hours due to one issue or another. Nothing about this game flows together nicely.

The amount of free content is minimal, at best; you will end up having to grind quests just to continue leveling up, and the interface is littered with frequent reminders of the things you could pay for. Unless you have a VIP subscription ($10/month) you will have only about five quests you can do per level, which will not offer you enough experience to advance, forcing you to redo them for even less XP than you earned the first time. The only workaround is being carried  through the game by someone 2-3 levels above you who can unlock quests on a higher difficulty, but then you'll be doing little more than watching them solo the dungeon. It's not fun, and you'll never catch up to a point where you can actually start having fun with them.

reviewText:
This is mostly Reviewed as something which is on steam.
If you like this game... get it outside of steam, as steam does zero support for it, even for things which involve its own end of things.
for the tl;dr swaggots: As a Steam game... Won't Reccommend.
why? because this is a steam review.

Also, because of this, having a Steam based forum is pointless, especially seeing as how there's a recorded level of less than 200 players averaging most servers originating on steam.
(This title should be removed from Steam completely)

I'd probably say go with anything else outside of the DnD franchise.
not many players. pretty dead. mostly solo focused. get repetitive and boring fast.
also, extremely pay to win and overpriced for everything.
the game is old.
very. old.
and glitchy, b/c its never been properly updated.
in short, just a warning, you'll be wasting over 10 gigs of precious hard drive space for something you'll probably never play.

This is the only time I'll say, for what it'll take to get the same gaming experience, Just go for World of Warcraft. its cheaper.
seriously. its way cheaper than this Freemium scam of a game. you can't even do most of the quests without buying your way into it.
the controls are very clumsy. and the graphics, even on highest settings feel wasted by the choppy gameplay and clumsy controls.
again, If i were to use World of Warcraft as an example, and trust me... I hate WoW and quit it after level 80 in wotlk, i'd have to give more credit to WoW as an MMO.

there's other MMO's on steam with a larger player base.

another annoyance: you have to log into a server first before you can see what characters you have saved onto it. if you forget.... you'll have a fun time of starting/closing your game.

actually, another game I'll actually reccomend over this is Warframe. sure, its not medevial or magical, but you'll have a better overall gaming experience with it.




Edit:
This game has some of the worst... and I mean WORST customer service I've ever seen in the history of all the games I've ever played and had to troubleshoot something out of.

Have you ever had to deal with that one customer service rep who actually asks stupid things like is your computer turned on? is it plugged in?" to that level of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ INEPT... wow. just wow. 3 weeks later
date: still e-mailing back and forth with them
hoursPlayed: and two other department heads. averaging about one response a week
