reviewText:
It's ok, but for me personally it lacks replay value that most games can offer in the same genre and anyone I knew that played this game said the same or something similar.  I run around with some very experienced gamers like myself; which allowed us to max out very quickly in this game (TOO EASY TO MAX OUT). Pretty dull in coloring, transparency, chunky controls and stop, move, stop, move action so lacks smooth transition.  Expansions add some flare, but just turn into the same feeling of no replay value the more and more you level. Even end game lacks compared to all other games I have played that are similar and it's mainly due to it being so easy in comparison. All expansions make it last a bit longer, but very quickly get to the same result. I grew up playing the table top and think it would be better than this example.  I played this game outside of Steam so time played is a bit higher than reported thru steam.

Did I have fun playing even though it required little to no effort = sometimes +1
Did I feel there was nice character development = sure +1
Did I like the character development = it was ok, but wanted more -1
Did I feel boss rewards were worth the effort = Yes and maybe too generous at times given the lack of effort to earn it -1
Did the mechanics feel satisfactory = some classes felt ok, but others felt very clunky -1
Did I like the character skill structure = yes, it individualized each class to stand out from the rest, some similar skills among classes but not enough to be too similar feeling. +1
Did I enjoy solo play = Only way to add some difficulty, but only lower levels, once mid-level everything was 1-2 hits. -1
Did I enjoy multiplayer = Yes +1
Did I enjoy the particle effects and actions = mostly +1

After that it's actually 5/10 which hits the crossroads of either recommend or not recommend, but if given a person newer to MMOs instead of someone like myself that has a lifetime of examples I would have to give DDO another +1 because it's a great starter MMO for your first, but not after graduating from hundreds into thousands of MMOs tried with max levels in all of them.

Sirspoony final rating 6/10 - so play the free game or wait for a sale!

reviewText:
It's a little sad.  This game was pretty cool when it came out, years ago.  I don't really see much difference in the early levels.

I read the wiki, and it looks like they gimped f2p even more--no more 32-point builds?  No thanks.

The game is fun, but having to grind each dungeon like 3, 4x to unlock something that shouldn't be locked in the first place.

Also, I see the game is still buggy, and some D&D rules are, like... what?

You're honestly better off with some sort of G+ hangouts/chatroom and diceroll generator and playing tabletop with people online.

reviewText:
This game is okay. ONLY FOR NEWBS TO D&D

First thing to look at is a comparison to Classic AD&D and this-

This game is LOOSELY based on the 3.5 Edition from 2003 and while they try to be faithful they fall short of the actual rule set especially now that the Fifth Edition is out. It is okay for people using basic D&D or Starter Sets without complete rules but anyone who has even some knowledge of the Advanced game will not be impressed by this especially since it is missing some key elements and classes that made the game so much more versitile.

Next are the Graphics... and oh good Lord all mighty these graphics didn't age well. Granted this game came out in 2006 but look at WoW: Came out in 2004 and they lasted long enough for a whole decade before being completely revised in the Warlords of Draenor expansion. These graphics (even on the HIGHEST settings) still look terrible. Now I don't personally have to much of a problem as I love classic Games and graphics way over the attempt of Uber Realism now but anyone who is a CoD, WoW, etc will be less than impressed.

Voice acting: Better than Two Worlds, not as good as Two Worlds II... or in terms everyone will understand: Better than Anakin Skywalker/Hayden Christensen, worse than Arnold Swarzenegger playing the Terminator (so worse than Monotone). It is not that good and leaves a lot to be desired.

Gameplay- Same as WoW practically. If you have played WoW you will feel at home pretty much. There are Character Creation differences but those are practically the same as Elder Scrolls Dagger Fall and Morrowind. The game plays like WoW almost to a tee in game.

Overall I would rate this game 6/10 for Newbs to D&D only.

If you are familiar to D&D then this would be 3/10

I don't suggest it. I suggest getting the actual board game. If you never want to play the board game then this is fine, otherwise don't get this.

reviewText:
Dungeons and dragons online is an abomination. I thought WoW was bad, but holy ♥♥♥♥! First off, Subscription, it's optional, without it you get a fairly decent game, filled with things you can't do because you won't give them money. So why buy a subscription? You get to waste your savings getting fictional currency, an exp boost and one or two classes which are free after some months of subscription, 99 dollars per year.
Turbine Points! The exciting piece, to get 23k Turbine points, it costs 200 dollars!(199.99) About 128 pounds according to Google. Rediculous, as The Druid class costs 1.3k turbine points, and to play as a half orc costs about the same, About 7 other classes and 3 other races also cost the same. You can only make 4 characters, or pay 600 points for another slot, this can be done 30 times.
The store is rediculous, blizzard are expensive in selling mounts for real money, but they don't come any where near the quantity of stuff these guys are smoking *Cough* Selling. 200-500 points For companions, which do nothing except follow you, Just like in WoW, but these cost money. You can only change their name once, or have to pay money to do so again.
Finally, it's very pay to win(Or Lose at life), you can buy experience and stat points to improve your character, becoming immensely overpowered, the more money you put into it. You can also buy the in game currency, in a much more direct way than you can on WoW nowadays.
This game is terrible, I don't recommend it, the graphics aren't anything special, especially considering it's only 9 years old and WoW is 10. I'd suggest playing Runescape instead, the graphics are prettier, it has nicer music and it's a lot cheaper for it's micro transactions.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game , I really wanted to love this because I adore the DND tabletop games I was looking forward to explore the DND world and have fun.

However as I slowly found out that most of my time with the game is waiting of it to start ( much of the time recorded is just me waiting for it to start up or load the game world or move to a new area) Sometimes the game crashes when entering a new area and I have to start up the game again and all progress lost!

Not only that but I soon found myself spending most of my time playing the same quests over and over again to get the exp for the good dungeons but most of the interesting ones are behind a pay wall or need more then one person to be workable without dying a million times.

The grinding wore out all the enjoyment I have when I started playing this game together with the crashes and the long wait times I just could not go on.

I will stick to the table top games ,at least your team mates can't pretend that you don't exist or worse troll you.

reviewText:
***AVOID AT ALL COST!***

Dungeons and Dragons Online is a once great game that not only jumped the shark, it filleted it, grilled it, and make shark fin soup out of its remains.  I loved DDO.  I've spent countless hours playing DDO over the past several years.  The addition of epic levels and destiies (level 20+) absolutely ruined the game, turning it into a complete grindfest of completing the same content over and over again as fast as you can run from the entrance of a dungeon to its exit.  The game is entirely about XP/min now, where anything worth having is easily available to anyone with the time to grind for it, lots and lots of time.

The worst aspect of the game is the difficulty levels.  In heroic levels (1-19), there really isn't anything that can't be face rolled on the most difficult setting by a grouip of first timers.  In Epic levels, normal and hard should be renamed cinematic mode, and elite should be renamed forget about it, unless you utilize extremely exploitative builds that remove all challenge from the game (most of which require nearly endless amounts of grinding to achieve).

If you live in your mom's basement and haven't seen the sun in months, DDO might be the game for you.  If you don't have any skill but all the time in the world to grind out stats, DDO just might be the game for you.  If you suffer from clinical depression yet do not wish to seek treatment but would instead prefer to spend all day every day in a virtual world where endless grinding will make you seem like a super hero, DDO is definitely the game for you.

If you want a balanced MMORPG that you can play a few hours here and there, yet still be able to take on any challenge the game has to offer through logical build choices that match your playstyle coupled with stategic use of your abilities, well, quite frankly, you need to keep looking.

reviewText:
BTW Steam shows I've played 0 hours. I've played waaaay more as I've regularly played DDO since Aug'2009 just not the Steam download (predate available via Steam).

DDO's a blast. Wizard's a perennial favorite but I think I've run nearly every class to at least 10. VIP, for 3 years now and counting. Highly recommended

UPDATE 2014-06-16: Highly recommneded

Pros:
* D&D -- lots of the traditional lore big and small. Spells, classes, general concepts, monsters and more. Cast Lightning Bolt and Cure Serious Wounds, use a Greataxe or Shortsword, wear Plate Mail and magic rings, fight Kobolds and Beholders and hunt down Ioun Stones and other classics. Nifty new toys too, but DDO draws on the rich tapestry of D&D's 40 years to provide a depth against which most games feel shallow and weak.
* 3.5ish Edition plus House Rules -- DDO uses a variant of 3.5 Edition. I first played Basic edition (yay Elf as a *class* :P) and enjoyed AD&D, up through 3.5 and not a fan of 4th edition so yay. Turbine's done a pretty good job taking D&D 3.5 and adapting it to an MMO. Some rules changed for the transition from pen-and-paper to MMO (spell points instead of Vancian N-casts-per-day, AC/PRR/DR/Dodge instead of just AC, etc), but overall they work pretty well. There's some kinks and the rules are tinkered with every so often to improve balance or new options but all in all a plus IMO.
* Rich(est) Character Creation -- there's many options for your character creation and progression. Go pure classed and you still have regular progression and choices of feats, skills and enhancements to evolve your character as you desire. Supports a wide variety of styles and gameplay with lots of replay value. Lots of tinkering, and the forums are full of advice on the various abilities and what works well (or doesn't) for different types of characters and playstyles.
* Meelee vs Ranged vs Caster -- plenty of variety in gameplay to suit your preferred playstyle.
* Active Combat -- unlike most MMOs where you click on a target and make a latte while the computer attacks for you,  DDO plays best if you put in some effort. Move out of the way of attacks, aim your spells and arrows, and generally be engaged in the gameplay. Auto-target is supported so you don't need FPS skills, but it's also not autopilot e.g. even if you've painted a target if you turn away your spell etc won't hit (or even be launched) because you do have to reasonably face the target. Some games you can play asleep (literally) but DDO keeps you involved.
* No PVP -- it's a purely PvE game. This avoids a slew of social problems in many games.
* Personal loot -- chests reward loot to each individual so no loot stealing, while also allowing you to assign an item to another player if you prefer they have an item instead. No stress mechanic.
* Community -- it's pretty common to run into folks that are friendly and helpful. It varies a bit depending on the time of day, season, server and luck, but I've found the general attitude is more welcoming than many MMOs.

Cons:
* Rich(est) Character Creation -- if you find WoW has the right level of character complexity (or perhaps too much), then you'll likely find DDO complicated. It's not EVE complex, but it's definitely not at the simpler end of the industry. The complexity has its merits, but it's not everyone's cup of tea. That may be you.
* No PVP -- if PVP's your thing, you'll hate DDO.
* No 'End Game' -- DDO doesn't really have an 'end game' like many MMOs. It's something the dev team has acknowledged and appears to be working on, though it likely will take some time to bake out. Right now when you tire of being level 20+, you can True Reincarnate" and start a new life with some boosted perks. As there's more quests for most of the game than you can run in a single life
date: this seems to work well all in all. I don't reincarnate very often and have little interest in an 'end game' so you'll need to look to others or folks on the forums (http://forums.ddo.com) for more information. That said
recommended: it can take a while to hit cap (a month for experienced folks
hoursPlayed: many months or more for less experienced folks who don't play a lot) so this may may not be much interest to you.\n* Forums emphasize Min/Max-ing -- the forums (unsurprisingly) have a larger % of advanced players than the mix of actual players in the game. This is good as it provides a lot of tips on gameplay
voteText: but can also be somewhat elitist and focus on min-/max-ing characters for the most difficult of gameplay. I've played for 5+ years on multiple servers

and only runs Epic Elite difficulty (hardest of the hardest). Understand forum posters are disproportionately more old hand and very advanced and take some of the comments with a grain of salt.

reviewText: This game is fairly unique, and not for the F2P thing. It hasn't aged that gracefully (though it doesn't look bad by any means), and they have made many concessions to appease solo players. That being said, playing this with a group of friends, adventuring together with 4-5 people, each filling a different classic D&D role, is a blast, occasionally verging on sublime. The bite size nature of each adventure makes it work for all sorts of schedules.

reviewText:
The best dungeon-based MMORPG I've ever played (and I mean that!).
Runs well in pretty much anything these days; has a great, and different, combat system than most of it's genre; is constantly being updated; and is totally free.
Well, about that free part, is really is totally free. Some classes are paid for, as dungeons and quests and more but you can grind favor points with your free characters and buy it all with those hard gained points, so... despite being a truly time eater if you try going the totally free way, it presents that option, and after all the grinding, you can really just have/do anything any Pay-to player has/does.
Anyway, just download the game and see for yourselves (also note that the game is meant to be played with groups! And it's also, in my opinion, one of the best MMORPGs for groups out there.)

reviewText: I don't know or care what an MMO" is.  All I know is that this game is a multiplayer action game that gets it right.   The action doesn't start until you are in a private instance with your small group.     It is an ACTION game.   You don't have to select a target to perform an action.  You don't click on an area on the ground to make your character move to that direction.    There are no restrictions whatsoever.    You *can* select a target and then cast a fireball and your fireball will go towards that target.  Or you can aim your fireball whereever the hell you please and fire it a few feet in front of where the monster is running to.     The magic system in this game makes other games look like peanuts.   Select where to cast things... position a firewall vertically in a doorway to have it hit the crowd of monsters trying to push through multiple times.    Not only is everything in the environment fair game and 'within the game world' (jump up on those barrels in the stock room to get out of those spider's reach.. or blow up the same barrels with the enemies on top of it to send them hurtling to the floor.   Its the underlying system of the game consisting of skills
recommended: rolls all put into an action game with hit boxes that literally leaves other games of the genre in the dust.   Other games just have you running through a plastic environment... here you jump through traps... maybe you were fast enough to avoid the blade entirely.. maybe you didn't in which case you have to make a reflex saving throw to avoid damage.      I highly recommend that everyone not only try out this game but also level a character to the higher levels to get a good idea of what the game is about.    Sadly they've dumbed it down a little especially the tutorial area which used  to have a very gritty steal some of these items from a grimey harbor area warehouse to now it takes place on a disneyesque island more directed at a younger crowd (I imagine to not scare as many people away)"

reviewText:
This game is the only genre you can find. It's the mix of MMORPG and PenNPaper.
You will find it confusing with the dice system if you didn't know what DND is.

Pro:
- Fun
- Designed for Intense gamer (grinding & building toons based on your like)
- Play with friends, strangers, or guild members
- Guilds are very helpful in this game, the 1st thing you should find is your guild (Recommended)
- A lot of contents, but do not expect to access them without progressing because you'll ended up in the Turbine store and handing out money from your pocket
- A lot of servers to choose
- Difficulties flexibility
- Challange mode available, it's the real challange and try not to complete it alone
- PvP available
- No Jerks, alot of wise people (grown up, even old people play this)

Con:
- Outdated graphic and UI
- Although it's available to both PC and MAC, it's better not to play on MAC (a lot of issues)
- Sometimes the combat will feels disconected, or out of sync
- Slow progression
- Steep learning curve and take times

reviewText: A lot of formerly pay to play games have went on the Free to Play model.  Many have got crippling penalties for free players that make it all but impossible or even extremely unenjoyable.  The most notorious of the F2P models being The Old Republic of course.\n\nDDO on the other hand does have limitations, but you still have a fair amount of totally free content.  Okay, free players are limited to 2 characters per account, but turbine points can unlock some things.  These you can buy yourself or earn through in game play.  It's an enjoyable enough game.

reviewText: Brings back memories of my pen & paper days.  The game is F2P(free to play) you can earn points to unlock content.  You can earn favor to unlock perks for your server.  The cash shop is balance.  Plenty of race & class choices to keep you comming back for more.  One thing i will note to fully bypass the small limit placed on new accounts all you have to do is buy the smallest point bundle or go VIP(pay to play) for at least one month.  The community in the game is great.  You can easily group with others to run dungeons & raids or just buy hirelings to join you for a set time.\n\nIf you love dungeon and dragons or just looking for a F2P game that's worth the time and effort then i suggest you check this game out.

reviewText:
I'm not really a fan of MMOs, but the setting and smallest change of adding manual blocking, dodging, and attacking really made it for me.

It's a fairly alright transfer from 3rd edition rules to video game, though knowledges are gone and most skills are focused on combat, such as Diplomacy being for reducing enemy threat, intimidate to increase it. Most dungeon areas are interesting and have non-typical MMO quests, along with secret doors, puzzles, and of course, enemies to fight.

It's also free to play, with most purchases in the store being easily bought with Favor that you earn from quests.

Overall, well worth a try.

reviewText:
This game is incredible, simply put. While it is P2W, there are certainly aspects on in that counter that. The following lists are not complete, I already feel the game calling me back.

Pros:
- customizability coming out of my ears. You can play the same class and race and still end up with totally different character builds from it.

- Leveling system. This is kind of part of the customizability, but on a different aspect. The leveling is much different from normal MMOs, since you get experience from quests and not actually killing monsters. While this makes grinding a bit harder, it also makes leveling more rewarding. There are also two different types of levels, ranks and actual levels. This makes it interesting to rank up due to the different bonuses.

- Addicting. I don't know what it is that draws me to this game, but I just can't stop playing it. It's absolutely amazing and ccompletely fun to play!

Cons:
- P2W aspects. Naturally, there must be money coming to the developers from somewhere since it's F2P. A lot of quests, classes, and races are locked to those who are willing to pay. However, I have learned that simply the experience boost from the monthly VIP is well worth the money.

- Starting area. If you like to experiment with classes, you will learn to hate the first island. You can choose to skip it after your first playthrough, but then you miss a lot of leveling. And that sucks. A lot.

reviewText: Dungeons and Dragons Online (DDO) is an MMORPG I can call home" because I will return to it no matter what other MMORPG I play. I started on September 2010 (before downloading it on Steam) in the Orien server and after purchasing a character switch to the Cannith server
date:
I am still currently active with this game. I remember the all-nighters I'd put into the game to grind for favor to purchase Pay-To-Play content. I've met interesting people over the years and I continue to meet new people in Cannith. DDO has been around for more than ten years and I give high respect to the developers for the continuing support to this game.

There are no perfect games out there of course. I want to share two of my biggest pet peeves in this game:
- The introduction of the champion system is painful and I fear for the new players that will experiment their first "Elite" difficulty dungeons only to get massacred by a champion. Champions are monsters with a flaming crown on their head and after being slain
recommended: they drop mysterious remnants which can be turned in for items. The mysterious remnants do not reward the effort of defeating a champion because from time to time
hoursPlayed: Turbine adds in the good rewards from time to time and you're not guaranteed the items you want. Usually the rewards are mediocre and other easier methods can be used to purchase the equivalent item. I would prefer for the champion system to have been optional to all players.\n- DDO has a fair share of lag where occasionally
voteText: if you're in a dungeon
helpfulPercent: you will not be able to interact with your character even after pressing all buttons (like jump
votesHelpful: casting a heal
votesTotal: etc) will not initiate action. You will be stuck and if you're surrounded by monsters
votesFunny: your character is good as dead due to the inability to heal and fight back.\n\nIn summary
commentsCount: I still enjoy DDO although it's outdated. Due to the amount of time I've invested in the game
column16: that investment still keeps me going because I know I can look back upon the experiences and memories I had in this game. Also
column17: I find it easier to stick to things I already know."

reviewText:
Before there were games like Pathfinder, there was but one big tabletop fantasy game that saw fit to rule them all- Dungeons and Dragons. Anybody who's ever looked at a d20 while cross-eyed has either at least heard of the game, knows someone who plays, or has rolled up a character and found themselves sitting at a table with a two-liter and a bag of cheese doodles. I'm one of the latter ones- I used to have a game night in college- not much any more though. But as far as properties upon Steam, well, there are two of them I pay attention to, and they're both ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes- and both are free-to-play. Both of them have their ups and downs. In this one, I'm paying attention to the aptly-named Dungeons and Dragons Online.

There are a number of different kinds of MMO out there- there's the kinds that style themselves after WoW, with the open-world, the questing, the grouping up, the tradeskilling... D&DO isn't like that- instead, I liken it to a one-player game of D&D, where the game itself is your own, personal DM to run you through adventures of various length. Adventures are broken up into three lengths- short, medium, or long crawls. Each adventure has specific goals and offers chests full of loot for when you finish them, and the loot tables do not hold back. You won't just find a suit of plate armor, you'll find yourself a suit of plate that has five or six words describing its effectiveness and special abilities, and there are a lot of them out there.

Combat and mechanics are run using either the 3rd or 4th edition of D&D- you'll actually get to see the d20's result on the screen- and yes you can still get nat 20's and absolutely wreck stuff.

There aren't really that many downsides, but they ARE there- for example, if you're limited to solo play, some classes are going to get absolutely wrecked without careful planning and a few barrels of healing potion- most of your casting classes except for healing, for example. I'd recommend a fighter or priest for your first time through, just so you don't get frustrated. Most of your treasure will be sold and converted to healing potions over the course of the game, so don't get too attached to any specific item; you'll be drinking potions like cans of Pepsi.

There is an in-game premium store, but it doesn't take Steam funbucks to buy things- instead, you need to buy something called Turbine Points" with a credit card or gift card and use those to buy adventure packs and other things. The really crappy thing is that if you don't buy them
date: you'll end up hitting a level limit
recommended: and be unable to progress. They've also hidden a number of options in Character Creation away behind paywalls- races
voteText: Epic Destinies (stories tailored around a specific character archetype)- if you want to run something like a half-elf
helpfulPercent: or a druid
votesHelpful: be prepared to fork over. I can understand that yeah
votesTotal: they have to make a profit
votesFunny: but still- really

column17: though.\n\nSome adventures are tailored for some classes and playstyles over others. There's an adventure in the second hub of the game that requires you to sneak around to steal a ruby from a bunch of kobolds. You are limited in the number of one type of enemy you can kill

column20: and you'll find yourself swarmed in no time unless you're using the right class.\n\nOf special note is the fact that they managed to get Wil Wheaton to come in and DM an entire adventure pack. I haven't played through it
column21: but to be honest

reviewText: I heartily recommend this game for any gamer who loves the Fantasy RPG genre. The hireling system they use is great, it allows me to adventure in dungeons and have good control of the others in my group. I love the rest and resurrection shrines, which have come in handy on those occasions that I have had bad luck. Having started my gaming career with the table top red box edition I was not too sure that a computer version of D&D would work, but DDO laid my fears to rest.

reviewText:
an interesting game with a few issues.

pro- good class selection
con- quite a few classes behind a paywall

pro-korthos island does a good job showing how to play the game/ tells you what sort of things to expect
con- not much going on. it's a decent ammount, but not a grand ammount.

pro- plenty of dungeons
con- not many dragons. (in my time playing, i have seen 1)

pro- great weapon variety
con-not many great weapons

pro- easy to make money
con- currency is all out of wack (i think i had nearly a thousand platinum before i was level 3) (currency goes copper silver gold platinum)

pro- plenty of ways to upgrade weapons
con- upgrade system is odd, you assign a weapon with a prefix, a suffix, and +1, +2, +3, +4, or +5, rather than upgrading the quality from +1 to +2. you have to have a +5 upgrade stone, token, thing to create a +5, so it's all or nothing in a way.

pro- you can choose to assign stat points and skill points on your own.
con- it tends to get a bit confusing

pro- you can dual and triple class a character, thief/cleric/barbarian for example
con-the ammount of truly good endgame builds are small
personal gripe- when you choose a second or third class, the first or second one you were leveling ceases to level. so you might be a level 1 thief/ level 4 cleric/ level 15 barbarian.

pro- plenty of options in the options menu
con- organisation is terrible, everything is jumbled together.

pro- SURNAMES. you can share the surnames with other people, for example Zombycow vonwilcome and zeligia vonwilcome
con-........i got nothin

pro- you can make plenty of characters on different realms
con- if you don't pay, you get to make 2 characters per realm

pro- plenty of adventures
con- many of the more rewarding ones need to be bought individually.

pro- randomized quest and chest loot makes for interesting rewards
con- randomized loot makes for useless rewards
pro/con-ish-ranomized loot leads to farming the same quest for money

pro- each quest has multiple difficulty settings
con- for many quests, the difficulty doesn't really matter

pro- quest xp is lowered for a difficulty setting each time you complete it
con- while there are many quests in the game, there aren't that many for you specific levels. this leads to playing the EXACT. SAME.QUEST. over and over and over again on higher and higher difficulties.


Is it worth playing? i think so. but it does have it's issues.

This game is pretty good and is really similar to his paper cousin.
The only problems I met are the restriction if you are not a VIP.
I reached level 5 with my character, and now i don't find any quest or area for my level which is not VIP-only.
I know it's a free to play, and the creators need an income, and i'm ok with that. The problem is when you cannot find something else to do but repeat the same quests on higher difficulty over and over. It might be a good idea to give the chance to increase your reward by doing a quest you've alredy done with stronger enemies, but it becomes boring when this is the only thing you can do.
I recommend this game if you're looking for a good FTP to have fun, maybe with friends, but please, try to make it more accesible for non paying users.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings about D&D Online, really. I love this game, but I hate it at the same time.

Short version:
Very buggy, very laggy, feels lonely and abandoned, a game which had and still has (some investment required...) great potential but turned into a micro-transaction hell (borderline P2W). So 'as is' I cannot recommend it I'm afraid.

Long version:
PROs - I love the classes, stats, feats, weapons, the world(!), everything that makes the game really, really D&D as if it was pen and paper, including the crazy-amount of work people put into working out and programming quests and recording story telling (actual DMs' narrations!) for instances.
It feels like I sit at the desk with my DM, and getting all the details for a colorful, great experience. Sugar and spice!
The fights can go epic, the instances are at least nice but many of them are just great, clever story lines, fun characters.

CONs - Controls are a little uncomfortable (but it's OK-ish, one can live with it).
The game's code is so messy it eats resources like a monster, sooner or later hangs up and literally no hardware or net can compensate lags to make them go away.
Bugs and sloppiness ruin gaming experience as well as the small things, like fights in instances regularly start at the same time as DM narration does, so story telling experience is ruined or is taken away from the player as one has to focus on combat. Also, item-icons are not tiny masterpieces (WoW), but minimalist graphics (e.g. old free mmos") put together in hurry (in mspaint?) so don't look very nice.

The charm of story lines and worked out instances go away on higher levels. It feels like hard work and a lot of details were added to the game when development was started
date: and it just got more and more sloppy as time passed and -probably- release date/deadline came closer.\n\nSadly
recommended: this rush was not compensated later

reviewText:
As someone who's been playing this since beta I can say this is a really awesome MMORPG compared to others. Yes, it may get a little confusing for those who are first starting. (Trust me, Korthos never existed and there was a much shorter tutorial way back when, but it gets better).

I highly recommend this to people who would enjoy dedicating hours on building special characters and putting time into them. Not only is this a great game to explore classes, it's also a good game to make friends with and is a conversation starter with my fellow peers once we talk about new updates! Sure the game has it's fair share of downfalls, bugs, and lag... but what game doesn't have that? If you have the patience, go for it!

As I write this, it's the 10th anniversary weekend! DDO has a lot of special events that go on every week whether it be 10% raid bonus or something rather, it helps with leveling your characters!

Also the community is very nice and ever so rarely you'll meet an elitist! Everyone is there to help you if you need it!

reviewText:
Before there were games like Pathfinder, there was but one big tabletop fantasy game that saw fit to rule them all- Dungeons and Dragons. Anybody who's ever looked at a d20 while cross-eyed has either at least heard of the game, knows someone who plays, or has rolled up a character and found themselves sitting at a table with a two-liter and a bag of cheese doodles. I'm one of the latter ones- I used to have a game night in college- not much any more though. But as far as properties upon Steam, well, there are two of them I pay attention to, and they're both ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes- and both are free-to-play. Both of them have their ups and downs. In this one, I'm paying attention to the aptly-named Dungeons and Dragons Online.

There are a number of different kinds of MMO out there- there's the kinds that style themselves after WoW, with the open-world, the questing, the grouping up, the tradeskilling... D&DO isn't like that- instead, I liken it to a one-player game of D&D, where the game itself is your own, personal DM to run you through adventures of various length. Adventures are broken up into three lengths- short, medium, or long crawls. Each adventure has specific goals and offers chests full of loot for when you finish them, and the loot tables do not hold back. You won't just find a suit of plate armor, you'll find yourself a suit of plate that has five or six words describing its effectiveness and special abilities, and there are a lot of them out there.

Combat and mechanics are run using either the 3rd or 4th edition of D&D- you'll actually get to see the d20's result on the screen- and yes you can still get nat 20's and absolutely wreck stuff.

There aren't really that many downsides, but they ARE there- for example, if you're limited to solo play, some classes are going to get absolutely wrecked without careful planning and a few barrels of healing potion- most of your casting classes except for healing, for example. I'd recommend a fighter or priest for your first time through, just so you don't get frustrated. Most of your treasure will be sold and converted to healing potions over the course of the game, so don't get too attached to any specific item; you'll be drinking potions like cans of Pepsi.

There is an in-game premium store, but it doesn't take Steam funbucks to buy things- instead, you need to buy something called Turbine Points" with a credit card or gift card and use those to buy adventure packs and other things. The really crappy thing is that if you don't buy them

column34: I will be the first player to go back and start playing D&D Online again!"

reviewText:
I LOVE this game. I'm a dedicated D&D tabletop player. I've been playing Pathfinder since it's inception. I know how it all works. I love that this takes D&D to a new level. You can actually play without friends because you can find others online to play with you with the LFG feature OR play with friends and have a blast solving puzzles and slicing enemies.

My recommendation to people new to the game like I was, but familiar with D&D: do NOT follow the pre-built path. Build your own. It will help you so much in the long run as the computer generated paths tend to put your points in the wrong things.

Make your own mistakes rather than letting a computer do it for you. This game is amazing, I would highly recommend paying for some of the features. The subscription is no worse than subscribing for any other MMO.
